title-group.article-title: Studying playoff qualification in motorsports via mixed-integer programming techniques

abstract.p: The present authors consider the widely popular Argentine Turismo Carretera car racing series, which consists of 11 regular phase races followed by five playoff races. After the regular phase, the first 12 racers in the standings qualify for the playoffs, which determine the champion. The present authors address the problem of determining, at any point within the regular phase, the minimum number of points that each racer must earn in the remainder of the regular phase in order to secure a playoff spot. Two mixed-integer programming models for this problem are presented, their properties and practical performance are analysed, and the obtained results are discussed.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Motorsports in Argentina is widely popular, being second in public preference only to soccer. There are four main stock car national categories, each featuring first and second divisions, as well as supporting categories. These four categories have a tight combined schedule, in such a way that every weekend at least one of them has racing action in each of the more than 30 major race tracks located throughout the country. There is racing action every weekend all year long, with the exception of three or four weekends devoted to a short summer break and national polls. In addition to these four main categories, there are national rally, motorbike, and enduro championships, as well as countless local stock car and karting categories.

The most popular racing category is the Turismo Carretera (TC) series, which attracts the largest numbers of fans to the racing venues and generates the highest audiences in live television and radio broadcasts. The TC is the world’s oldest motorsport active competition, dating back to its beginnings in 1937 with the notable participation of the Formula 1 legend Juan Manuel Fangio, José Froilán González, and the brothers Oscar and Juan Gálvez. The cars are 3 litre carburated NASCAR-like tourism cars, Ford and Chevrolet being the brands with the largest fan bases.

The annual TC championship spans 16 races. Since 2008, the first 11 races are called the regular phase and the remaining five races are called the playoffs. The first 12 racers in the standings at the end of the regular phase qualify to the playoffs, and the playoff winner is the annual champion. At the beginning of the playoffs all points are reset to zero with the exception of the regular-phase winner, who starts with seven points. All racers take part in the five playoff races, but only the points earned by the 12 qualified racers are taken into account for determining the champion.

Different playoff systems have been in use in other racing categories in the world. The objective of this competition system is to add more excitement towards the end of the regular phase (as there is interest to determine which racers will qualify for the playoffs) and to open the championship definition to more racers (as usually many racers reach the last playoff race with chances of becoming the champion).

This work addresses the problem of determining the minimum number of points that each racer must earn in the remaining regular-phase races in order to qualify to the playoffs independently of the points earned by his/her competitors. In other words, from a certain location during the regular phase, it is desired to determine for each racer the number
ρ
of points that he/she must earn in the remainder of the regular phase in order to guarantee that no scenario exists in which the racer earns
ρ
or more points and does not obtain a playoff spot. Integer programming (IP) and mixed-integer programming (MIP) are the most natural mathematical and computational tools for tackling this problem, as it admits a clean combinatorial optimization structure [1, 2]. In this work two MIP models for this problem are presented, their properties are analysed, and algorithmic ideas are proposed in order to speed up their solution times. These models were successfully applied during the 2010 championship.

Different approaches for determining the minimum number of points guaranteeing playoff qualification have been previously applied for soccer [3], hockey [4–7], and baseball [8]. These sports feature matches between pairs of teams according to a prespecified schedule. In contrast to this situation, in motorsports no matches are held between pairs of teams but all the racers compete with each other at each race, and the number of points that each racer can earn varies within a larger range (e.g. at each TC weekend a racer can earn from 0 to 27 points, with half-points also being available).

The remainder of this work is organized as follows. Section 2 gives more details on the problem that is the focus of interest, and two alternative MIP models are presented for this problem. Some properties of these models and a simple technique for reducing the model size are also discussed. Section 3 provides some computational results in order to assess the practical performance of these models, the experience with the data from the 2010 competition is reported. Finally, section 4 closes the paper with some conclusions and remarks for future work.

sec.title: 2 Problem Formulation
sec.p: In this section the competition structure of each TC racing weekend is specified, and two MIP models for determining the minimum number of points that each racer must earn in order to secure a playoff spot are presented.

Each weekend race comprises testing, qualifying, and racing sessions from Friday to Sunday. After the qualifying rounds, the fastest racer gets 2 points for having obtained the pole position. The racers are then evenly divided into three groups and on Sunday morning each group takes part in a short race, called qualifying series. The winner of each of the three qualifying series earns 5 points, the second earns 4.5 points, the third earns 4 points, continuing in this way until the tenth racer, who earns 0.5 points. The remaining racers get no points from the qualifying series. The weekend concludes with the final race, in which all the racers take part. The starting order for the final race is determined by the qualifying series results. After the final race, points are awarded to the racers up to the 42th racer according to Table 1. According to this description, any racer can earn between 0 and 27 points at each weekend. After the regular phase, the first 12 racers in the standings qualify for the playoffs.

sec.title: 3 Computational Results
sec.p: In this section the computational results obtained with the modelling machinery described in the previous section are presented. Throughout this section, Model B refers to the model described in section 2.2, and Model B* to the enhancements in the binary search implied by Proposition 2. Section 3.1 reports on computational experience in order to analyse the possibility of successfully solving these models in practice, and section 3.2 presents experience with the 2010 regular phase.

sec.title: 3.1 Computational performance
sec.p: Unlike linear programming models, not every MIP model arising in practice can be routinely solved by standard computational machinery. This is a typical situation even with small-sized MIP models, and in this case one must resort to more involved computational techniques [1, 2]. It is, therefore, relevant to explore whether the proposed models can be solved for the TC regular phase.

Table 2 summarizes the running times and solved instances for the three proposed models during the 2010 regular phase. The column ‘Unsolved’ shows the number of racers

The MIPs were coded in the zimpl modelling language [11] and solved with Cplex 9.1 [12] on a 2.10 GHz Intel Core 2 Duo CPU with 2 GB of RAM memory.

sec.title: 3.2 Experiments for the 2010 competition
sec.p:
This section reports on the experience with the proposed models during the 2010 regular phase. After each racing weekend the models were executed in order to update the points needed by each racer, also obtaining which racers were already qualified for the playoffs. Table 3 summarizes the results for the last four weekends in the regular phase, including the number of racers with
ρ ( r ) = ∞
, i.e. those racers who, even winning all the remaining points at stake, depended on their competitors’ performances in order to ensure a playoff spot. The seven racers qualified with one weekend to go included the racer who would become the 2010 champion, Chevrolet’s Agustín Canapino, who was located in the 5th position in the standings and 65.5 points behind the leader.

sec.p: In contrast, Fig. 4(b) shows the performance of Ford’s Mariano Werner, who dramatically entered the playoffs in the last regular phase race. He abandoned the final race in the last weekend, thus earning only one point. However, the model had predicted that this was enough for him to qualify, independently of the final race result. The live TV broadcast took advantage of this knowledge, bringing relief to the Ford fans.

Although the interest of these calculations arises when approaching the end of the regular phase, the model provides valuable information during the first racing weekends. For example, Fig. 5 depicts the standings after the 4th racing weekend (i.e. with

Note that there are 25 racers with less than five points, and all but seven racers need 100 points or more in the following seven races in order to secure a playoff spot independently of their competitors’ performances. This is a difficult requirement to meet, as usually no more than 15 racers get 100 points or more throughout all of the regular phase, meaning that most racers will endure a hard time in order to qualify. In fact, the seven racers who were qualified with one weekend to go (last row in Fig. 3) included five racers from the leading pack in Fig. 5, with seven races remaining.

sec.title: 4 Conclusions and Final Remarks
sec.p: In this work the problem of determining the minimum number of points that a racer must get in order to secure a playoff spot independently of his/her competitors’ performances within a motorsports tournament has been presented, and it has been shown that this problem can be successfully tackled with MIP techniques. The proposed models have been applied to the 2010 season of the Argentine TC competition, making it possible to state some interesting conclusions.

list-item.p: With three races left in the regular phase, the leader Gabriel Ponce de León secured his qualification by winning the pole position. The live TV broadcast emphasized this point before the Sunday activities, a far-from-obvious fact for manual calculations.

With two races left in the regular phase, the pack of racers located between the 16th and 29th positions in the standings depended on their competitors’ performances, as
ρ ( r ) >
54
for all of them. This set of racers included two former TC champions, thus providing an additional interest to this information.

Although Mariano Werner abandoned the final race in the last regular phase weekend, the model had predicted that the single point he had earned was enough for him to qualify. Dramatic as his playoff qualification was, Werner was one of the strongest racers during the playoffs.

sec.p: The computational results obtained with these models received much attention from the specialized press during the last three regular phase weekends.

As lines of future research, it would be interesting to study the theoretical properties of this problem as, for example, the polyhedral structure of both MIP models as well as its computational complexity. It would also be interesting to extend these models to alternative playoff qualification systems or to similar motorsports competitions.
